awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improving Power Grids Weather Resilience through Model-free Dimension Reduction and Stochastic Search for Optimal Hardening
awd_abstract_narration:
Severe weather is the leading cause of power outages in the United States, leading to tremendous economic and social costs. Given days-ahead weather forecasts, hardening power lines can significantly mitigate cascading outrage risks, shorten the time to restore electricity, and therefore improve power grids weather resilience. Due to resource constraints, such as time and/or budget, it is important to identify the optimal hardening plan with the constraints. Given the large number of power lines on the grids, searching for the optimal subset of power lines of hardening is challenging.  In this research, a novel searching approach for optimal hardening plan with practical constraints is studied. The method takes the advantages of high-dimensional data analysis from statistics and discrete optimization via stochastic simulation from operations research and makes fundamental theoretical and algorithmic advances to optimize power grids hardening plans and reduce cascading power outage risks in severe weather. Because of the broad economic and societal importance of power grids, the research has broader impact on the welfare and security of the country.

This project develops a model-free dimension reduction method to improve the computational efficiency of discrete optimization via simulation for improving power grids weather resilience through optimal power line hardening. The dimension reduction method ranks the subsets of the transmission lines according to power loss caused by their disconnection from power grids. The new method does not need to assume a specific statistical joint model between power loss and all considered line combinations and only uses the marginal information of the line combinations, and thus are generally applicable for hardening planning. A new stochastic search algorithm that exploits the dimension reduction capability is then proposed to reduce the size of the effective search space given resource constraints when preparing for severe weather conditions. To improve computational efficiency, the stochastic search algorithm uses an informative Gaussian mixture prior to incorporate dimension reduction results while achieving asymptotical convergence and constructs a hierarchical sampling distribution using dimension reduction results. The model-free dimension reduction and stochastic search algorithm are generally applicable to a variety of other disciplines, e.g., the protection of other critical civil infrastructures such as road networks.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed a new computational framework to optimize power grid hardening plans to mitigate the impact of weather-related disruptions and improve power grid weather resilience. The computational framework has two integrated components that represent algorithmic advances in Statistics and Operations Research fields. The first component is a new dimension reduction algorithm that ranks the criticality of power lines using only the marginal information of a massive amount of high-fidelity power grid cascading outage simulation data, without specifying a complicated joint distribution model. The cascading outage simulations are conducted offline on a very large number of Monte Carlo generated initial disruption scenarios with multiple power line outages that are beyond the scope of traditional N-1 contingency planning. To evaluate the impact of line outages on load shedding, the new model-free dimension reduction algorithm generalizes sure independence screening in a scenario with all binary covariates and nonlinear relationships. It enables the identification of two or higher order power line interactions that are associated with large-scale cascading outages and may not be revealed based on N-1 analysis or experiences. The second component consists of new simulation optimization algorithms devised to exploit the criticality ranking to accelerate simulation-based optimization of power grid hardening decisions under tight time constraints in response to severe weather forecast. Two important advances in simulation optimization algorithmic research are made. First, a new multinomial sampling distribution model has been developed to seamlessly integrate the criticality ranks of power lines obtained by the developed model-free dimension reduction algorithm to speed up the convergence of a globally convergent model-based simulation optimization algorithm. Second, a robustly optimal sampling technique has been developed to incorporate the effect of distributional parameter estimation errors into the determination of the sampling allocation ratio. This innovation greatly improves the small-sample performance of simulation optimization algorithm for the intended use to determine optimal power grid hardening plans in preparation of severe weather conditions when computing budget is highly constrained with a limited decision time window. Numerical experiments were conducted using both benchmark test functions and high-fidelity power systems cascading outage simulator in collaboration with Argonne National Lab on widely used power grid test systems. Results have demonstrated both the accuracy of the criticality ranks of up to three-way combinations of power lines using the model-free dimension reduction algorithm, and the tremendous improvement in simulation optimization efficiency using the criticality rank information under a constrained computing budget.

 

Thanks to its flexibility and simplicity, the new dimension reduction method has very broad applicability and can be used to study a wide range of network-based problems such as transportation, supply chain, social network, and cybersecurity. The advances made in simulation optimization also have broader impacts for a wide range of domains where the complexity and uncertainty in system performance often make simulation optimization an indispensable decision support tool. The research outcomes of the project have been disseminated to statistics, operations research, and power systems research communities via conference presentations and peer-reviewed publications. The PI has also established connections with both utility companies and ISO researchers that will further facilitate the dissemination of research outcomes and real-world impacts. The project has also provided partial support for a domestic PhD student who has successfully defended his PhD thesis and is now working in a research organization as an Operations Researcher.
